channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: London's Trendiest Office Space - Lead and Mid-Level Perl Developer roles
item.description: I love working in a vibrant, modern space. If youâ€™re going to spend all day at work, it might as well be somewhere you enjoy being, rather than a cubicle farm. This client has a workspace Iâ€™m actively jealous of!

item.title: Be a trailblazer in a time of growth - Full Stack Architect required for a rapidly expanding London company
item.description: We recently started to advertise a developer role at a financial services company thatâ€™s growing in a bamboo-like fashion. We can now confirm that theyâ€™re also looking for some top talent to help lead this expansion. If youâ€™re currently a senior full stack developer looking to take on your next role as an architect then this is a great opportunity to do so in a company that is both ambitious and supportive. Increased job satisfaction is another perk, as their codebase is notably new and clean and the team are committed to using modern practices.

item.title: Fancy an all-inclusive trip to The Perl Conference next year*?
item.description: I attend a lot of Perl conferences and itâ€™s always interesting to see which employers are well-represented with a lot of delegates and which employers have little or no presence. This company is up there among the most prominently represented at a number of the European conferences, and shows a real commitment to staying at the cutting edge of Perl. In-house, the focus on training and development continues with a strong mentorship programme â€“ a large number of their Senior Developers started there in Junior roles.

item.description: September 7-8, 2018 Bern.

item.title: Nordic Perl Workshop and MojoConf 2018
item.description: September 6-7, 2018, Oslo.

item.title: The Perl Conference in Europe
item.description: August 15-17, 2018, Glasgow. The Call for Papers is open.

item.title: NLPW - Dutch Perl Workshop 2018
item.description: July 7, 2018, Arnhem, The Netherlands

item.title: The Perl Conference in North America
item.description: June 17-22, 2018, Salt Lake City.

item.title: French Perl Workshop
item.description: May 18-19, 2018, Paris.

item.title: A decade of classes in Lausanne
item.description: May 14-18, 2018, Lausanne. Five training classes by Damian.

item.title: Craft-Conference Budapest May 8-9, 2018
item.description: There is also a hike in the hills of Budapest after the conference.

item.title: The Perl Conference Newsletter: 04/26/2018
item.description: With information about The Perl Conference in Salt Lake City, UT, USA between June 17 â€“ June 22.

item.title: Perl Toolchain Summit 2018 Wrap-up Report
item.description: As part of some of the other work going on, there was progress made towards a tighter integration of the CPAN river data in the MetaCPAN API. Also, we now have access to Neil Bowersâ€™ CPAN river data generator. Thereâ€™s a plan to have MetaCPAN directly generate this data, rather than having us pull the data from him.

item.title: I went to the Perl Toolchain Summit in Oslo!
item.description: They're small events with about thirty people, all of whom are there by invitation. The idea is that the invitees are people who do important work on "the toolchain," which basically means "the code used to distribute, install, and test Perl software modules."

item.title: Perl Toolchain Summit 2018
item.description: This is always an amazingly productive event and in my opinion, if your company is looking to help Perl, there are very few better ways to do so than sponsoring this event.

item.title: Perl Toolchain Summit 2018
item.description:
Working on toolchain is a hard job, since you have to support all the old versions of the software, and will be blamed and criticized for â€œfixing broken featuresâ€ because people are relying on these broken features.

This is why Perl Toolchain Summit is so valuable so that I can get together with these people, exchange ideas and get a great moral support.

item.title: Perl Toolchain Summit 2018 report
item.description: For the community, having so many high-caliber people able to spend dedicated time on the infrastructure of Perl is a hugely effective way of getting things done and making the most of volunteer time. Having the right people in the room means that almost no question is too obscure to get an answer from at least one of the attendees.

item.title: Better Predicting Wine Cultivar with Feature Selection
item.description: This is the first post of my son on his journey to Data Science: Showing how to use 'Feature Selection' to improve the prediction model.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Every developer should have a blog. Hereâ€™s why, and how to stick with it.
item.description: I agree with the title and with most of the points. It is very easy to get started writing on Medium or GitHub Pages where you can also connect your own domain name. If you write about Perl, feel free to send me a link and you might get an audience of a few thousand people to your new blog. It would be great to see a few new authors included in this newsletter!

item.title: slurp mode - reading a file in one step
item.description: How can you find a string in a file that might start on one line and end on another line? It would not be easy to do it if we read the file line-by-line.

item.title: readline() on closed filehandle in Perl
item.description: A new entry in the Common Warnings and Error messages in Perl series in which I give examples of code that trigger specific warning and errors in Perl together with alternative explanations.

item.title: Test2 Manual Completion Report
item.description: The Test2 Manual grant has been finished. Read the detailed report here.

item.title: March 2018 Grant Votes
item.description: The request 'Perl 6: Bugfixing and Performance of Rationals Fixing Constraints on Constants' was approved.

item.title: A new Linux distribution with Perl as its heart
item.description: RSLinux-v1.01 is a new Linux distribution with its package manager, build configurations, and a demo one liner init system all written in Perl.

item.title: Moo at System::Image::Update
item.description: It is more of an introduction to Moo than a show of hardware.

item.title: Perl RaspberryPi eBook fund raiser, goal reached!
item.description: $2,668 USD raised by 114 backers. 107% of the $2,500 goal.

item.title: winmorbo - Tool to make Mojolicious Development server "morbo" work well in Windows
item.description: Introducing the winmorbo batch script.

item.title: Websocket Extension for GUIDeFATE - Dialogs and File Operations
item.description: GUIDeFATE - GUI Design From A Text Editor is a Quick-and-Dirty GUI designer for newbies. Websockets provide persistent two-way connection between web client and web server. Now together.

item.title: Bigger Baby Moose
item.description: The first bug found in the code.

item.title: Baby-Step-Moose
item.description: Writing tests for Baby Moose.

item.title: Nordic Perl Workshop 2018 Call for Papers
item.description: The Nordic Perl Workshop and MojoConf 2018 will be held in Oslo, on September 6th and 7th. CFP submission dead line June 1th 2018.

item.title: What after the Pull Request Challenge?
item.description: Mohammad and myself had a short session of remote pair programming. The immediate result was a Pull-Request in the Dancer2 project. The more interesting result is that now Mohammad offers to have pair-programming sessions to work on issues in the CPAN ecosystem.

item.title: #353 - Working together at the PTS or in remote pairs
item.description:
Hi there!

We have plenty of reports from the "Perl Toolchain Summit" that gathers some of the core contrbutors of the infrastucture behind CPAN. It is an excellen opportunity for them to work together and improve the life of every Perl developer. Working together in the same space has a huge positive impact on them.

From a totally different direction Mohammad Anwar offers his time to remotely pair-program with anyone who would like to work on a CPAN related task. This type of cooperation is great both for newbies and for seasoned developers.

Enjpy your week!
